article.title: Domain-wall excitations in the two-dimensional Ising spin glass

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the auxiliary graph in the middle panel represent?
choices: A minimum spanning tree on the spin lattice.
A minimum-weight perfect matching on the frustrated plaquettes.
A random configuration of spins on the dual lattice.
A schematic representation of the domain wall energy.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the "windowing technique" illustrated in this figure?
choices: To determine the ground state of systems with open boundary conditions.
To efficiently calculate the domain wall energy for systems with free boundaries.
To extend the ground state calculation to systems with toroidal boundary conditions.
To visualize the spin configurations for different coupling distributions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the scaling behavior of the different algorithms shown in this figure?
choices: The branch-and-cut algorithm outperforms matching based methods for all system sizes.
The windowing technique leads to a constant overhead compared to calculations for PFBC.
The matching approach for PFBC shows exponential scaling with system size.
The spin-glass server implementation is most efficient for large systems with PPBC.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main assumption underlying the equation df = 1 + 3/[4(3+Î¸)]?
choices: The validity of droplet theory for describing 2D spin glasses.
The existence of a direct relation between domain wall energy and length.
The applicability of stochastic Loewner evolution to the bimodal model.
The description of the 2D spin glass by a non-unitary conformal field theory.
